Text.Value: How peculiar. Smooth face, cobbled edges. They're a sign - they must be.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Stonemason Kith facing away from player, looking at rubble.

Text.Value: The rock. The rubble. All of it, if I may be so bold.
*Nothing odd catches your eye.*
What do you think?
There is nothing fancy about good work. Respect the stone, or it may crush you.
*You recall the tale of a Sharran fortress armed with impenetrable adamantine - a metal created by a gnomish mage.*
The past is nearer than we think. We simply must dig.
You don't talk like the rest of your crew. Fancy britches, are you?
Survey the area for unseen curiosities.
Clan-sen, my friend - my sore eyes have seen what they're able. Care to offer yours in their stead?
What luck. Look here, hoon - I seek fresh eyes. Care to lend yours to a weary mason?
A sundweller in these parts? Look here, my top-side friend - I need fresh eyes. And I doubt I'll find fresher.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: The stonemason turns to you and addresses you directly.

Text.Value: How fascinating. I told my kinfolk that book-learning has its benefits.
*The duergar listens to your tall tale. Though sceptical of the more suspect details, they seem amused enough by the story.*

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: The duergar watches the player tell a tall tale, amused.

Text.Value: ... until a great hellbeast charges through, toppling the walls and crushing the people!
A crafty gnome helping forge a fortress that would last an aeon.  Mythic metal atop stone hewn by the devoted.
*Two styles, two eras. The statue was carved from newer stone and erected by late-comers to this ancient fortress.*
That's to say nothing of this tale of an invulnerable protector - it's unfortunate the Sharran's successors found no proof.
*The book's style was not particularly gripping, and as such, its contents are tough to remember.*
As you need.
I know everything about this place. In fact, it was hand-forged by a flumph called Grym...
Untold centuries later, a new tribe revives it. Fresh walls, fresh sculptures...
Leave.
Please - a quick look, if you don't mind.
Peering into cracks and crevasses in hope to find history's morsels.
Examine the fallen rubble.
Take a look. Tell me what you see. And be thorough.
How fares your investigation?
And you have been thorough?

EditorData.logicalname: Player did not do all three checks.

Text.Value: Leave.
I have come up regrettably short. I hope you might see truths where I cannot.
Leave.
Fascinating... What begat such a powerful flumph? Does it still live here to this day?
Ease your suspicions - I've got no mind for slaving. My passion is stone, and my god is the chisel.
But these learned eyes reach their limits. And so I must humbly request yours.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Stonemason gestures to his own eyes.

Text.Value: Examine the fallen rubble.

EditorData.InternalNodeContext: this skillcheck only if the player has neither REALLY_DWARF or REALLY_DEEPGNOME

Text.Value: Anything standing out?

EditorData.logicalname: Logic node - player did all three checks

Text.Value: The True Soul, the battle - too many distractions. There is still truth to uncover.
Fine. What should I be looking at?
Leave.
Try to remember the tome 'Fables of Forges Grym'.
*You consider the differences, but they mean nothing to you.*
*The hottest of flames smoothed the stone and left sulphuric crystals behind. The fires of the Hells have touched Grymforge.*
*There was also whispers of the gnome's secret project - an invincible guardian - though its existence was never proven.*
That's all, then.
How exactly does a flumph hand-forge anything?
Alas, you've left me with more questions than answers. My survey continues.
Yes, the rubble - it was a great beast that tore these walls down. I should have known.
I would like to trade.
An ancient city, hewn from the stone by disciples of Shar, later abandoned.
*Boulders and stone bricks of various sizes clutter the corridor, many split cleanly in two. Yet some walls remain fully intact.*
Deliver your report.
I could use more time.
But my work has only begun. There is more still to find. I must get to it!
Assess the statue for technique and composition.
Let's see what you've got.
What are you doing, exactly?
*No quake brought these rocks down - they were smashed through in an instant. Something big charged through here. Something very big.*
As rare as a smile in Sschindylryn, you might say. But I've no skill for slaving - I prefer chisel to cane.
I am ready to report my observations.
*What this pattern signifies, you can't fathom.*
Doesn't explain this infernal plate I found, though. Here, take it, perhaps you'll be able to figure it out why it's here.
Incredible - an entire history, risen from dirt and debris! Picture it:
The statue is newer than the fortress, you say? So obvious in hindsight.
Heh - that explains the infernal plate I found. Perhaps you might have use of it.
*Several glassy stones stand out in the debris. Their borders are coated with tiny yellow crystals.*
*The statue's meandering curves and golden edges stand out against the weathered masonry behind it.*
Recite the tale you remembered from your reading.
I prefer evidence, hard as stone. Look again, what can you see before you?
Sulphur. Of course! The rocks have been altered by hellfire.
Leave.
A suspiciously eager welcome from a duergar.
A friendly welcome? A rarity in the Underdark.

Synopsis: Duergar looking at stonework. Gruff sounding but surprisingly sophisticated. He asks you to examine the stonework and responds with his interpretation based on what you tell him
